Description: Scarab carved from steatite; no division lines on back; underside inscribed with finely incised and shaped hieroglyphs arranged horizontally with, from right to left, Maat feather, walking goose (or duck?) and sun-disc; fine incised details within signs; hole lengthwise; complete.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (according to museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Naukratis provided various scarabs and scaraboids, in glazed composition, Egyptian blue and steatite with a similar inscription (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 83-85; Gorton 1996, 102-103, type XXVIII B, esp. no. 24). Depending on the identification of the bird, a goose or a duck, its translation can be either a cryptographic reading of the name of Amun-Ra, the goose being a sacred animal to him, or the motto 'Shu, son of Ra' (for both readings: Magnarini 2004, 317, 10.55). Drioton translated this trigram by Amun (Drioton 1957, 17, no. 5). Although the registration list of Boston states that this stone scarab was discovered in the Scarab Factory (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming), it is uncertain that it was produced locally. On the other hand, variants of this type, found in many examples and made out of glazed composition or Egyptian blue, were definitely produced there (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 83-88). The precise and naturallistic style in which the hieroglyphs are engraved is comparable with other scarabs bearing the same inscription. One was tentatively dated to the 25th dynasty (scarab in glazed composition: Magnarini 2004, 317, 10.55). Another was found in Cerveteri in Etruria dated to the second half of the 7th century BC (scarab in steatite: Hölbl 1979, 34, pl. 74/1, no. 109. For the latter, Hölbl mentions a parallel from the tomb 268 in Monte Abatone, near Cerveteri, that belongs to the first half of the 6th century BC. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hölbl, G. 1979, Beziehungen der ägyptischen Kultur zu Altitalien (EPRO 62/II), Leiden. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Magnarini, F. 2004. Catalogo ragionato di una collezione di Scarabeo-Sigillo Egizi, BAR International Series 1241. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 175)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.46) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
